statement.p:
Let A \and B be sets.
A \subseteq B \iff (x \in A) \to (x \in B)
x \in A \cup B \iff x \in A \lor x \in B
x \in A \cap B \iff x \in A \land x \in B
x \in A \setminus B \iff x \in A \land x \not\in B
A = B if and only if A \subseteq B and B \subseteq A.

Prove that if S is any set:
\phi \subseteq S
S \subseteq S

li.p: The logical statement we're trying to prove is (x \in phi) \to (x \in S)
Assume that x \in \phi. This is false, since nothing is in the empty set. That means that the conditional statement (x \in \phi) \to (x\in S) is vacuously true. Thus \phi \subseteq S.
The logical statement we're trying to prove is (x \in S) \to (x\in S)
Assume that x \in S. Then x \in S is trivially true. Thus S \subseteq S.

statement.p: Verify the following set identity by using the basic identities in the table above: A \cap (A \cup B) = A.
